awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: StructNet: Constructing and Mining Structure-Rich Information Networks for Scientific Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Science disciplines have been generating huge volumes of research publications, which are of tremendous value but far beyond researchers' capacity to digest and analyze.   There is a critical need to automatically (with the help of widely available, general knowledge-bases) transform research text into structured information networks on which advanced search and analytics tools can be developed to facilitate researchers and practitioners to quickly locate knowledge, make inferences, and even generate new scientific hypotheses.

This project aims at developing a new data-to-network-to-knowledge (D2N2K) paradigm to transform massive, unstructured but interconnected research text data into actionable knowledge, by integrating semi-structured and unstructured data. First, organized heterogeneous information networks (hence called StructNet) are constructed, and then powerful mining mechanisms on such organized networks are developed.  With a focus on biomedical sciences, the project investigates the principles, methodologies and algorithms for (i) construction of relatively structured heterogeneous information networks (called MediNet) by mining biomedical research corpora via attribute extraction, relation typing, and claim mining, and (ii) exploration and mining of the networks so constructed via graph OLAP and task-guided embedding. The project develops an extensible framework to facilitate literature-based scientific research. The study on construction and exploration of MediNet not only impacts biomedical research but also consolidates this data-to-network-to knowledge methodology, readily to be transferred to other domains,  for automatic transformation of massive unstructured text data in those domains into structured and actionable knowledge.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Science disciplines have been generating huge volume of research publications, which is of tremendous value but far beyond researchers’ capacity to digest and analyze.   There is a critical need to automatically (with the help of widely available, general knowledge-bases) transform research text into structured information networks (knowledge graphs) on which advanced search and analytics tools can be developed to facilitate researchers and practitioners to quickly locate knowledge, make inferences, and even generate new scientific hypothesis.

This project aims at developing a new data-to-network-to-knowledge (D2N2K) paradigm to transform massive, unstructured but interconnected research text data into actionable knowledge, by integrating semi-structured and unstructured data. First, organized heterogeneous information networks (hence called StructNet) are constructed, and then powerful mining mechanisms on such organized networks are developed.  With a focus on biomedical sciences, the project investigates the principles, methodologies and algorithms for (i) construction of relatively structured heterogeneous information networks (called MediNet) by mining biomedical research corpora via attribute extraction, relation typing, and claim mining, and (ii) exploration and mining of the networks so constructed via representation learning. The project develops an extensible framework to facilitate literature-based scientific research. The study on construction and exploration of MediNet not only impacts biomedical research but also consolidates this data-to-network-to knowledge methodology, readily to be transferred to other domains, for automatic transformation of massive unstructured text data in those domains into structured and actionable knowledge.

The project has delivered constructed COVID-19 specific knowledge graphs from PubMed and has made significant contributions to COVID-19 related research. The project has developed several well cited GNN tools, including HGT, that are broadly used in both academia and industry, for graph mining and learning. Advanced tools that integrate symbolic reasoning and representation learning have been developed to better incorporate human heuristics (knowledge) into the loop of learning process. Logical rule mining algorithms have been developed that can lead to potential new scientific hypothesis. In the last year of the project, we have successfully addressed issues related to accountability, fairness, and causal inference in the regime of graph learning. The impact of the project is cross-disciplinary and beyond academia. The research team has won several best paper awards and one test of time award. The knowledge has been disseminated to different communities via keynotes, tutorials, and courses. The team has also made significant contributions to outreach activities, including founding the UCLA Summer Institute for high school students and setting up diversity scholarships for underrepresented students.


Last Modified: 11/08/2022
Modified by: Yizhou Sun
